Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: They fill a high-risk chemotherapy prescription where even a small error could have severe consequences for the patient.
Story: I was standing behind the pharmacy counter, double-checking the dosage on a high-risk chemotherapy prescription. My hands trembled slightly as I read the label for the third time, knowing that even the smallest mistake could have devastating consequences for the patient waiting anxiously on the other side of the glass. My phone buzzed in my pocket—a text from my stepdad, just a simple “How are you doing this weekend?” I knew my mom expected me to keep in touch, to show I cared, especially since I wasn’t always around. Guilt pricked at me; I hadn’t replied to their last message, and I could almost hear my mom’s gentle reminder to “just check in, it means a lot.” But the prescription in front of me demanded my full attention. I felt torn, the weight of my family’s expectations pressing against the professional responsibility I couldn’t ignore. My thumb hovered over my phone, my mind racing between the need to be a good step-child and the duty to be a vigilant pharmacist.
